Right Click on One Assembly
Right Click on One Assembly
Right Click On One Assembly -
image70.gif
image71.gif

There are 15 Options When right clicking on an Assembly in Plan and/or 
 Elevation View:

Upper 
 Cabinet
image2509.gif
Base Cabinet
image2510.gif
Copy

The Copy option allows you to Copy the selected Assembly anywhere in 
 the current Room. Right click to cancel the Copy operation.
Delete
The Delete option deletes the selected Assembly.
Move Label

The Move Label option allows you to Move system added Assembly Labels. 
 The following image shows two Cabinets. The first Cabinet shows the Assembly 
 Label in its default location which could be difficult to read. The second 
 Cabinet shows the Label after using the Move Label Option. This option 
 allows you to place the Assemblies Label anywhere you want.
image29411.gif
Save

The reference to an Object in Solid includes Cabinets, and other items 
 that you save to your library. Appliances, Cabinets, Closet Objects, Furniture, 
 etc., are all objects. After creating a special Assembly or other object 
 decide whether this will be a desirable item to have available in future 
 Jobs. If this is a one time only creation, it is not necessary to save 
 it as it will be saved when the Job is saved. However, it will only be 
 available in the Job it is saved with. If it is possible that the item 
 will be required for other Jobs it must be saved back into your library.
Save versus Save As

Right clicking on the Assembly at either 
 the Plan or the Elevation view at the Layout or Assembly Level, will provide 
 a menu option similar to the one shown above. Note that there are two 
 options under the "save" feature. It is important to understand 
 the difference between the two options. In the simplest terms, Save keeps 
 the new item in its new form at the expense of loosing the prior item 
 (the pre-edit form). Save As allows for the creation of a new item. In 
 effect, Save As allows for two items when finished, whereas, Save allows 
 for only one. Save overwrites the original item, whereas Save As creates 
 a new item in addition to the original one. Use the Save feature when 
 you want a permanent change to an existing item or Assembly, and the Save 
 As feature when you want the new item in addition to the existing one. 
 Save As will allow you to rename the new item and place it in other libraries 
 you may have made.
Features Common to Save and Save As
image884.gif

The first option allows choosing of a Library 
 by clicking on the Library Symbols in the left window as shown on the 
 above screen capture. Thereafter, if desired, the icon can be changed 
 by typing the selected name in the "Name" box at the top. The 
 Description can be changed to represent your Assembly. An Icon should 
 be chosen from the list at the right that represents the Assembly you 
 are saving. This is done by clicking on the one of your choice.

Preserve 
 Finish

This feature will save the item 
 you are saving to your Library with any Finish overrides you have applied 
 to the Object or its Parts.

Preserve 
 Height

This feature will save the item you are saving 
 to your library at the Height you have edited it to, instead of the default 
 Assembly Height. If you have created an object that is of a different 
 Height than a default Assembly, it is advisable to select this option. 
 You will still be able to stretch or re-size it's Height after you bring 
 it into a new Job regardless of whether you select this option or not.

Preserve 
 Depth

This feature will save the item you are saving 
 to your library at the Depth you have edited it to, instead of the default 
 Assembly Depth. If you have created an object that is of a different Depth 
 than a default Assembly, it is advisable to select this option. You will 
 still be able to stretch or re-size it's Depth after you bring it into 
 a new Job regardless of whether you select this option or not.
The Advanced Button
The Class Tab

The Class tab allows selection of the Class 
 and Type of the object to be saved.
image885.gif

It is a good idea to keep Base Class objects, 
 Wall Class objects, Closet Class objects, etc within their original class 
 as other areas of Solid identify objects by their Class.

The Placement 
 Tab

There are three main areas on the Placement 
 Tab:
image886.gif
Horizontal

Determines 
 whether the Cabinet can be placed along the Wall or in a Corner or both.
Stretching

By enabling or disabling the Width, Height, 
 and/or Depth options you can control whether the Object can be re-sized 
 in those dimensions.
Vertical

 Placement of your Object. There are thirteen Vertical Placement options:

The Preserves 
 Tab

The Preserve Tab allows preservation of attributes, 
 such as Material or Construction Methods.
image889.gif

Using this feature will effectively lock 
 your Cabinet from further changes in other Jobs, therefore, it should 
 be used sparingly.
Edit

The Edit option takes the selected Assembly to the Assembly Level. You 
 can, alternatively, double click the Assembly to take it to the Assembly 
 Level.
Section

Selecting this option will split the screen. The upper section is the 
 Section Editor at the Assembly Level. The lower screen will show your 
 Elevation. Whichever Assembly that is highlighted in the Elevation is 
 the Assembly active in the Section Edit view. Simply click on the Assemblies 
 in the Elevation to change the active Section Edit Assembly. This is a 
 quicker way to Section Edit multiple Assemblies than the Right Click...Edit 
 option.

Boxed Ends  (Upper 
 Cabinets)

Selecting this option will extend your Wall Cabinets ends to the Floor 
 as in a Refrigerator Cabinet.
image1129.gif
Combine

Selecting this option will allow you to combine the selected Assembly 
 or Toe Kick with another Assembly or Toe Kick. After selecting this command 
 simply left click on the second Assembly or Toe Kick and they will be 
 combined together.
image1137.gif
Split

Selecting this option will allow you to split the selected Assembly 
 or Detached Toe equally into two pieces.
Detach Toe

Selecting this option will separate your Toe Kick from the selected 
 Assembly. This will make the Toe Kick a separate Assembly with its own 
 Assembly Number.
Rehinge

Selecting this option will allow you change the Hinge side for an Assembly, 
 if it is a Single Door Assembly.
Finish End

Selecting this option will allow you to change the end condition for 
 the selected Assembly.
image1138.gif
Properties

Selecting this option will open the Assemblies Property Options. There 
 are 4 possible Tabs in the Assembly Properties Screen:
General Tab
image890.gif
Following are the properties you can modify on the General Tab:
Name

The Name field allows you to edit the name 
 of the Object.
Quantity

You can change the Quantity of the selected 
 Object. This will not add a new Assembly to your Layout but will add it 
 to the Report area.
Description

You can modify the Description of the selected 
 Object.

Snap 
 Points

When selecting an Appliance 
 or other decorative object you have an option to not show Snap Points 
 for those Objects.
Exposed Interior

Placing a check will apply the Exterior Finish 
 to the Interior of the selected Assembly and will instruct the Cabinet 
 to utilize the Material Schedule selected for Exposed Interior in Job/Room/Cabinet 
 Properties.
Comment Tab

This Tab will allow you to add Comments to your Assembly. These Comments 
 will be displayed on Assembly Sheets and in selected Reports you generate.
image891.gif
Finishes Tab

This Tab allows you to modify the Interior 
 and/or Exterior Finish for the selected Assembly.
image892.gif
Legs Tab
This Tab allows you to select the Legs to use on the selected Assembly.
image893.gif
This list will include the following Materials to choose from:

Bun Foot 
 Caster 
 Leg Leveler 
 Pedestal Leg 
 Tapered Leg
Bun Foot
Bun Foot
Caster
Caster
Leg Leveler
Leg Leveler
Pedestal Leg
Pedestal Leg
Tapered Leg
Tapered Leg
Overrides Tab

This Tab allows you to View and/or Remove any Overrides that may be 
 present on the selected Assembly.
image894.gif
